Collaborative Research: Impacts of Energy Extraction and Coal-Fired Power Plants on Disinfection By-product Formation in Water

Increased energy extraction activities, including shale gas extraction and conventional oil and gas extraction, are resulting in high releases of bromide (and potentially iodide) to U.S. surface waters. New pollution controls being installed at coal-fired power plants are also resulting in high releases of bromide ion. These activities are presenting new issues for human and ecological health because when these high-bromide/iodide waters are chlorinated (a disinfection processes used in water treatment), they can result in the formation of highly toxic disinfection by-products, several of which may have adverse human health effects.

The proposed interdisciplinary research would comprehensively characterize and quantify brominated and iodinated disinfection by-products formed in source waters impacted by energy extraction and coal-fired power plant releases, determine potential human and ecological health risks, and use modeling to establish and quantify the linkage between impacted source waters and human exposures, and estimate maximum loadings of bromide and iodide that will minimize human risks.

While it is known that high levels of bromide and iodide can contribute to the formation of brominated and iodinated DBPs in chlorinated drinking water, even "conventional" disinfection by-products formed by reaction of chlorine with bromide, iodide, and natural organic matter (NOM) are not fully characterized, such that >50 % of the halogenated disinfection by-products remains unknown. This situation is even more complex when considering the possibility of additional chemicals used in energy extraction/utilization processes that are often unknown (particularly for hydraulic fracturing). No longer are the disinfection by-product precursors only from natural organic matter, and low levels of contaminants in domestic wastewater, but there are now additional precursors from these new energy extraction/utilization releases, which are largely uncharacterized. This is already resulting in significantly different exposures to both humans and aquatic organisms. Understanding the formation of these brominated and iodinated disinfection by-products and their potential human and ecological risks could ultimately inform decisions regarding control of bromide and iodide releases and what levels would be deemed safe.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Drinking water sources are affected by natural and anthropogenic processes that can alter their treatability. Organic matter and other constituents react with disinfectants during drinking water treatment to form disinfection byproducts (DBPs). When bromide concentrations are elevated in drinking water sources, the rate and extent of DBP formation increases, and speciation shifts toward brominated forms, which exhibit higher toxicity and are associated with negative health outcomes (e.g., cancer) at lower concentrations than chlorinated DBPs. Thus, increases in brominated DBPs are expected to increase the health risks in treated drinking water.

Bromide, which is naturally present and sometimes added to coal for air quality benefits, is captured in wet flue gas desulfurization (FGD) systems at coal-fired power plants and not typically removed from FGD wastewater prior to discharge. During rulemaking for the 2015 Effluent Limitations Guidelines and Standards for the Steam Electric Power Generating Point Source Category (ELGs), the EPA acknowledged the potential for downstream effects, but used a narrowly constrained (8 km) geographic proximity analysis that did not consider populations of affected systems. Our work shows that significantly more people are downstream of wet FGD discharges, and multiple power plants can affect a single drinking water intake. For Pennsylvania, 2.5 million consumers are potentially affected (compared to 150,000 identified by EPA). On a national level, 3.5 times more people are potentially affected.

Despite its effect on DBP formation and health risk, wastewater discharge contributions to bromide concentrations are poorly understood due to a lack of monitoring in rivers and at discharge locations. To fill critical gaps, we developed a coal-consumption based load model to evaluate the effects of coal-fired power plant wet FGD discharges on bromide contributions at downstream drinking water sources. Using the load model and a geospatial flow path assessment, downstream drinking water vulnerability was assessed. Such information provides context for water utilities and regulators for the case-by-case FGD bromide regulation recommended by the 2015 Steam Electric Effluent Limitations Guidelines and Standards (ELGs). Given the recently announced intention of U.S. EPA to re-open and re-consider the ELGs for treatment of FGD discharges, this work is especially timely.

While coal consumption has declined in recent years, consumption at wet FGD facilities has increased. Concurrent with increasing use of halogen addition for meeting air quality regulations or securing federal tax credits, this has increased FGD bromide discharges in the U.S. Using 2016 coal consumption data, the median predicted bromide concentration from these facilities was 16 micro-g/L. 19.5 million people are predicted to be affected (14.6% of 134 million people served by surface water facilities in the U.S.). Half the locations were affected by more than one wet FGD discharge.

We also measured bromide and iodide in hydraulic fracturing (HF) and FGD wastewaters, and treated them in the laboratory using chlorine and chloramines to simulate impacted drinking water.  Bromide ranged from 29-125 mg/L and 5.4-10.5 mg/L in the HF and FGD discharges, respectively.  Iodide ranged from 13.6-53.5 mg/L and 0.58-0.84 mg/L in the HF and FGD discharges, respectively.  These levels are much higher than natural freshwater levels in the U.S. Our study is the first to show that high iodide levels can be released in FGD discharges. When HF wastewaters were treated with chlorine, a large number of brominated DBPs were formed, and when treated with chloramine, a large number of iodinated DBPs were formed, including many new DBPs not reported previously. Four of these newly identified iodinated DBPs were cytotoxic, especially 2,4,6-triiodophenol, which was more cytotoxic than all trihalomethanes and most haloacetic acids currently regulated. Natural geogenic organic compounds in HF wastewaters were found to be potential precursors. New brominated and iodinated sulfonate DBPs were also identified in the chlorinated and chloraminated HF wastewaters, likely formed from sulfonate surfactants used in the HF process.  Thus, HF impacts on drinking water have both natural and anthropogenic inputs. 

Moreover, while brominated DBPs were highest in the chlorinated samples, cytotoxicity was higher for the chloraminated samples, which contained more toxic iodinated DBPs. Quantitative data for ~50 DBPs also showed higher levels of Br-DBPs for chlorinated waters and higher levels of I-DBPs for chloraminated waters. Therefore, while chloramine is commonly used at drinking water treatment plants to lower regulated trihalomethanes and haloacetic acids, HF impacts may be a concern for waters treated with chloramine. Finally, overall, DBP levels were much higher in HF and FDG impacted drinking water compared to non-impacted waters. Therefore, HF and FDG releases may impact the ability of drinking water treatment plants to meet regulatory limits and may also contribute to an increased human health risk.   

Overall, these results demonstrate that HF and FGD wastewaters can contribute to drinking water with a higher toxicity and can potentially increase risk to human health. Thus, the release of these waters should be controlled and minimized.
